awd_titl_txt: GP-IMPACTS: Nevada's GeoGateway Program: A collaboration between Nevada State College, College of Southern Nevada, and the Desert Research Institute
awd_abstract_narration:
The American Geoscience Institute and the U.S. Bureau of Labor project a shortfall of 90,000 geoscientists by 2024 and that by 2020, Nevada (NV)  will need 260 more geoscientists, 50 more atmospheric and space scientists, 340 more environmental scientists, 70 more hydrologists, and 210 environmental science technicians. The Yale Project on Climate Change concluded that the majority of Clark County residents, 70% of NV's population, has a poor understanding of climate change issues. Increasing student exposure to geoscience education and increasing the number of geoscience prepared graduates entering the workforce in NV and the U.S. is the primary program goal. Field-based, experiential learning and research experiences are two high-impact practices generating deeper learning and higher retention. The merit of the proposed project rests on integrating practices that increase student interest and engagement in geoscience-related degrees and careers. The GeoGateway Program (GGP) has the broadest impact in increasing introductory students' scientific literacy and access to geoscience education through lesson plans based in real-world environmental change data and other experiential, field-based opportunities.  The number of students transferring from the College of Southern Nevada (CSN), NV's largest community college will increase because the colleges' articulation agreement includes mentoring and enhanced advising for students majoring in Environmental and Resource Sciences (ERS), a major including high geoscience content.  Gender demographics at both colleges demonstrate growing numbers of underrepresented minority females, especially Hispanic females, entering science fields. Students majoring in ERS will complete a significant research project or internship in collaboration with the Desert Research Institute (DRI), a specialized environmental research arm of the Nevada System of Higher Education, or other local organizations to further scientific knowledge of living sustainably in the dry southwestern U.S. This knowledge is critical for the communities in the region because as millions relocated here, climate change exacerbated the severity of droughts, fires, and other arid climates features. GGP graduates will be job-ready for geoscience jobs or to enroll in related graduate programs created to support state and national geoscience goals.

The GeoGateway Program (GGP), a structured pathway linking academic and research institutions in southern NV to train the region's new generation of geoscientists, will recruit and engage students taking geoscience-related coursework. Two-year Associate of Science (AS) graduates will channel into NSC's four-year ERS program. The GGP leverages commitments and staff from CSN and the DRI by accessing infrastructure already supported by NSF, the Nevada Climate-ecohydrology Assessment Network (NevCAN). Within four years, the GGP will reach more than 530 CSN and 680 NSC students through jointly-programmed introductory curriculum, guest lectures, field trips, and film screenings designed to generate 25% growth in ERS majors and a 25% increase in ERS graduates. CSN students graduating with an AS degree will directly transfer all relevant coursework into the NSC ERS degree, enter the GGP and participate in a Special Topics research project, receiving critical supplemental advising and mentorship from faculty and a near-peer GGP Ambassador. The large pool of potential undeclared NSC ERS majors will be recruited into ERS. By the end of the GGP, program partners will have strengthened the community college pipeline into a four-year degree program to help meet the nation's need for geoscientists. Other outcomes include the effectiveness assessment of the jointly-coordinated programming and participation in research or internships, by measuring geoscience knowledge gained and level of participant interest in pursuing geoscience-related degrees/careers, and the impacts of increased faculty advising and use of peer mentors, especially on recruiting and retaining underrepresented minorities and female students in science programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: NSHE Board of Regents on behalf of Nevada State College

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of Nevada?s GeoGateway Program rests on activities, practices, and processes resulting in increased student interest and engagement in geoscience-related degrees and careers. The Program involved college students from the College of Southern Nevada (CSN, a primarily 2 yr institution), the Desert Research Institute (a research branch of Nevada?s university system), and environmental and resource science (ERS) majors and others from Nevada State College (NSC), the only 4 year institution in southern Nevada.  In person field trips brought an estimated 200 students from NSC, CSN and University of Nevada Las Vegas to wild places such as Desert National Wildlife Refuge and the Amargosa Valley in southern Nevada. Students experienced first-hand a variety of geoscience activities such as collecting stream macroinvertebrates (like crayfish and dragonflies), the Nevada Climate-ecohydrological Assessment Network (NevCAN) monitoring network for collecting critical data on climate change locally, and plant ecology of the Mohave Desert.  A new virtual field trip was created during the pandemic, and will be used by others who are unable to attend in person.  Stronger collaboration with CSN broadly, and specifically much stronger ties with faculty from CSN Henderson only a few miles away, has resulted in greater numbers of CSN students enrolling in ERS degree program at NSC.   Student workers-- ERS majors  called ?Geoambassadors?-- were effective in meeting diverse students in their classrooms, visiting dozens of classes over the duration of the award.  They also impacted students through a ?virtual classroom visit? they created.  The combination of in person advising by the CSN faculty and meeting our Geoambassadors helped to increase the numbers of students transferring from CSN to NSC and becoming ERS majors.  Strengthened collaboration with NSC?s Transfer Office made it easier to work more closely when recruiting CSN students.   Development of a website (in Canvas, which is the teaching/learning platform used at NSC) for archiving of NevCAN data, activities, virtual field trip, virtual recruitment presentations etc https://nsc.instructure.com/courses/2501359  made it easier for faculty and students at both NSC and CSN to access unique climate monitoring data, recordings of  previous environmental science seminars, and share data across campuses.  Students at CSN and NSC used NevCAN data in class projects and in research presented at NSC?s Undergraduate Research and Creative Works Conference.  Our ERS Colloquium series held an average of about 8 events each year, reaching an estimated 400 students over the span of the award.  We established the Eunice Foote Scholarship, focused especially on women and first generation college goers to encourage students to earn their ERS degree.  Program success in part helped convince our Administration to fund a new faculty line, allowing us to hire a 3rd full time faculty, this one a geoscience specialist, which helped expand our course offerings in geoscience courses and our guest lecture/seminar series. Our just approved minor in Environmental Health and Sustainability is to begin fall 2022; our ERS faculty helped create this degree.

The GeoGateway Program had several broader impacts. Increased numbers of students enrolled in our introductory geoscience courses, and a higher percentage of these were non-white.  We saw a substantial increase in the numbers of dual credit students taking introductory environmental science courses at several local high schools for college credit.  Our faculty made numerous visits to other high schools and high school events to encourage high school students to consider environmental and resource science as a career.  The numbers of transfer students from CSN declaring ERS as their major has gone up significantly during the four years of the award.  The number of ERS majors jumped 50% from 2018 to 2022, and more of these have declared themselves as non-white.  Graduates per year with ERS degrees almost doubled by the end of the award, and the percentage of these self-declaring as non-white increased significantly. More than half were female.  Increased numbers of ERS majors participated in an internship program at NSC over the span of the award, including with Desert Research Institute, Garden Farms, and nearby federal agencies.  Graduates are now working with the Bureau of Land Management, non-profit ecology restoration groups, Desert Research Institute researchers, and Garden Farms. More opportunities for internships developed for our students through the ?Lunch with a Geoscientist? series, which brought in professional geoscientists from agencies such as Republic Services, the Las Vegas Valley Water District, the City of Henderson, and others.

The GeoGateway Program operated August 2018 to July 2022, largely overlapping with the COVID-19 pandemic.    This greatly complicated normal college processes and engagement with students.  Despite substantial impacts to students, faculty and staff disrupting some of our planned activities, we developed alternatives and maintained project scope.  We modified some of our approaches to cope, and are pleased to say we still made a difference for those students who were part of the program.


Last Modified: 08/30/2022
Modified by: Paul Buck

por.por_txt_cntn:
The intellectual merit of Nevada?s GeoGateway Program rests on activities, practices, and processes resulting in increased student interest and engagement in geoscience-related degrees and careers. The Program involved college students from the College of Southern Nevada (CSN, a primarily 2 yr institution), the Desert Research Institute (a research branch of Nevada?s university system), and environmental and resource science (ERS) majors and others from Nevada State College (NSC), the only 4 year institution in southern Nevada.  In person field trips brought an estimated 200 students from NSC, CSN and University of Nevada Las Vegas to wild places such as Desert National Wildlife Refuge and the Amargosa Valley in southern Nevada. Students experienced first-hand a variety of geoscience activities such as collecting stream macroinvertebrates (like crayfish and dragonflies), the Nevada Climate-ecohydrological Assessment Network (NevCAN) monitoring network for collecting critical data on climate change locally, and plant ecology of the Mohave Desert.  A new virtual field trip was created during the pandemic, and will be used by others who are unable to attend in person.  Stronger collaboration with CSN broadly, and specifically much stronger ties with faculty from CSN Henderson only a few miles away, has resulted in greater numbers of CSN students enrolling in ERS degree program at NSC.   Student workers-- ERS majors  called ?Geoambassadors?-- were effective in meeting diverse students in their classrooms, visiting dozens of classes over the duration of the award.  They also impacted students through a ?virtual classroom visit? they created.  The combination of in person advising by the CSN faculty and meeting our Geoambassadors helped to increase the numbers of students transferring from CSN to NSC and becoming ERS majors.  Strengthened collaboration with NSC?s Transfer Office made it easier to work more closely when recruiting CSN students.   Development of a website (in Canvas, which is the teaching/learning platform used at NSC) for archiving of NevCAN data, activities, virtual field trip, virtual recruitment presentations etc https://nsc.instructure.com/courses/2501359  made it easier for faculty and students at both NSC and CSN to access unique climate monitoring data, recordings of  previous environmental science seminars, and share data across campuses.  Students at CSN and NSC used NevCAN data in class projects and in research presented at NSC?s Undergraduate Research and Creative Works Conference.  Our ERS Colloquium series held an average of about 8 events each year, reaching an estimated 400 students over the span of the award.  We established the Eunice Foote Scholarship, focused especially on women and first generation college goers to encourage students to earn their ERS degree.  Program success in part helped convince our Administration to fund a new faculty line, allowing us to hire a 3rd full time faculty, this one a geoscience specialist, which helped expand our course offerings in geoscience courses and our guest lecture/seminar series. Our just approved minor in Environmental Health and Sustainability is to begin fall 2022; our ERS faculty helped create this degree.

The GeoGateway Program had several broader impacts. Increased numbers of students enrolled in our introductory geoscience courses, and a higher percentage of these were non-white.  We saw a substantial increase in the numbers of dual credit students taking introductory environmental science courses at several local high schools for college credit.  Our faculty made numerous visits to other high schools and high school events to encourage high school students to consider environmental and resource science as a career.  The numbers of transfer students from CSN declaring ERS as their major has gone up significantly during the four years of the award.  The number of ERS majors jumped 50% from 2018 to 2022, and more of these have declared themselves as non-white.  Graduates per year with ERS degrees almost doubled by the end of the award, and the percentage of these self-declaring as non-white increased significantly. More than half were female.  Increased numbers of ERS majors participated in an internship program at NSC over the span of the award, including with Desert Research Institute, Garden Farms, and nearby federal agencies.  Graduates are now working with the Bureau of Land Management, non-profit ecology restoration groups, Desert Research Institute researchers, and Garden Farms. More opportunities for internships developed for our students through the ?Lunch with a Geoscientist? series, which brought in professional geoscientists from agencies such as Republic Services, the Las Vegas Valley Water District, the City of Henderson, and others.

The GeoGateway Program operated August 2018 to July 2022, largely overlapping with the COVID-19 pandemic.    This greatly complicated normal college processes and engagement with students.  Despite substantial impacts to students, faculty and staff disrupting some of our planned activities, we developed alternatives and maintained project scope.  We modified some of our approaches to cope, and are pleased to say we still made a difference for those students who were part of the program.
